comments:
As an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance, this course develops the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include the following: 1) the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; 2) uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; 3) security market efficiency; 4) optimal capital structure, and 5) dividend policy decisions.

Students for the most part commented the course was “solid with useful knowledge.” The course is a very good introduction to the principles of corporate finance and is well structured, with defined modules and a clear progression through material. However, a few students complained the course placed too much emphasis on calculations and “more in depth analysis on concepts might be recommended to build a better foundation for higher level thinking.” 

A majority of the students raved about Professor Mackinlay, saying he is “fantastic” and is clear and articulate in explaining concepts after years of experience. Many students said he is very fair and loved his style of teaching, such as using a chalkboard instead of projections. One student even claimed “I couldn’t have gotten a better first glimpse into the world of finance.”

Many students in this course were Wharton students completing their core curriculum. However many students believe, “this is a great introduction to finance and is an immensely useful class all Penn students should take.” Since Mackinlay hand writes all of his notes, going to class is typically required to learn the material. The workload is not overwhelming or demanding, and there are three exams and two homework assignments.
